Module Contents¶

class geometry.Inlet¶

Class defining and holding all geometrical data for the inlet of a centrifugal machine Currently not in used and to be defined better. For now, copy the impeller inlet.

_hub_diameter¶

Hub (inner) diameter \(D_{\mathrm{hub}}\) of the centrifugal machine’s impeller

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_tip_diameter¶

Tip (inner) diameter \(D_{\mathrm{tip}}\) of the centrifugal machine’s impeller

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_area¶

Inlet area for the fluid flow: \(\frac{\pi}{4} \left(D_{\mathrm{tip}}^2 - D_{\mathrm{hub}}^2\right)\)

Type:

float, defaults to 0

Note

TODO Define correctly the class as an inlet and not a derived impeller (in case there’s an IGV) and use it in the code.

_hub_diameter = 0¶
_tip_diameter = 0¶
_area = 0¶
compute_area()¶

Computes the inlet area for the fluid flow as \(\frac{\pi}{4} \left(D_{\mathrm{tip}}^2 - D_{\mathrm{hub}}^2\right)\) and sets _area

_tip_diameter \(D_{\mathrm{tip}}\) and _hub_diameter \(D_{\mathrm{hub}}\) should be set by the user before calling compute_area()

class geometry.IGV¶

Class defining and holding all geometrical data for the Inlet Guide Vane (IGV) of a centrifugal machine Currently not in used and to be defined better. For now, copy the impeller inlet.

_hub_diameter¶

Hub (inner) diameter \(D_{\mathrm{hub}}\) of the centrifugal machine’s impeller

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_tip_diameter¶

Tip (inner) diameter \(D_{\mathrm{tip}}\) of the centrifugal machine’s impeller

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_area¶

Inlet area for the fluid flow: \(\frac{\pi}{4} \left(D_{\mathrm{tip}}^2 - D_{\mathrm{hub}}^2\right)\)

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_position¶

IGV angle in radians

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_mid_diameter¶

Mid line diameter \(D_{\mathrm{mid}}\)

Type:

float, defaults to 0

Note

TODO Define correctly the class as an inlet and not a derived impeller (in case there’s an IGV) and use it in the code.

_hub_diameter = 0¶
_tip_diameter = 0¶
_position = 0¶
_mid_diameter = 0¶
_area = 0¶
compute_mid_diameter()¶

Computes the mid line diameter as \(\sqrt{\frac{D_{\mathrm{hub}}^2 + D_{\mathrm{tip}}^2}{2}}\) and sets _mid_diameter

_tip_diameter \(D_{\mathrm{tip}}\) and _hub_diameter \(D_{\mathrm{hub}}\) should be set by the user before calling compute_mid_diameter()

compute_area()¶

Computes the inlet area for the fluid flow as \(\frac{\pi}{4} \left(D_{\mathrm{tip}}^2 - D_{\mathrm{hub}}^2\right)\) and sets _area

_tip_diameter \(D_{\mathrm{tip}}\) and _hub_diameter \(D_{\mathrm{hub}}\) should be set by the user before calling compute_area()

class geometry.Impeller¶

Class holding all the data to define an impeller geometry

_inlet_diameters¶

inlet diameters of hub \(D_{\mathrm{hub}}\), mid \(D_{\mathrm{mid}}\) and tip \(D_{\mathrm{tip}}\) line in this order.

Type:

3x1 array of floats, defaults to [0, 0, 0]

_inlet_blade_thickness¶

inlet blade thickness of hub, mid and tip line in this order.

Type:

3 x 1 array of floats, defaults to [0, 0, 0]

_inlet_blade_angle¶

inlet blade angle of hub, mid and tip line in this order in radians.

Type:

3 x 1 array of floats, defaults to [0, 0, 0]

_outlet_diameter¶

outlet diameter of the impeller, usually written \(D_2\).

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_outlet_blade_height¶

outlet blade height defining the impeller, usually written \(b_2\).

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_outlet_blade_thickness¶

outlet blade thickness.

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_outlet_average_blade_thickness¶

average thickness of the blades at the outlet of the impeller taking into account a taper ratio of the blade (thickness at hub and tip are different)

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_outlet_blade_angle¶

outlet blade angle of the impeller in radians, usually written \(\beta_2\).

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_axial_extension¶

axial extension (height) of the impeller.

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_blade_running_clearance¶

blade running clearance used for clearance loss, usually written \(\epsilon\).

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_number_blade_full¶

number of full blades. If there are splitters, full number of blades / 2.

Type:

int, defaults to 0

_splitter_blade_length_fraction¶

splitter blade length fraction ie. length of splitter vs a full blade.

Equals 0 or 1 if no splitter are used.

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_blade_length¶

length of a blade according to :cite:t:`1970:Jansen`. W. Jansen, Inst. Mech. Eng. Internal Aerodynamics, 1970.

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_blade_length_meanline¶

length of a blade at the meanline computed by numerically integrating the geometrical definition of the blade.

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_effective_number_blade¶

effective number of blades. Differs from _full_number_blade_w_splitters insofar as it’s not necessarily an integer. Used for the slip factor.

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_full_number_blade_w_splitters¶

total number of blades including splitters.

Type:

int, defaults to 0

_hydraulic_diameter¶

hydraulic diameter of the impeller.

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_inlet_area¶

inlet area.

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_throat_pitch_blade¶

pitch of the impeller at the throat for the hub, mid, tip lines in that order.

Type:

3x1 array of floats, defaults to [0, 0, 0]

_throat_width¶

opening width of the throat for the hub, mid and tip lines in that order.

Type:

3x1 array of floats, defaults to [0, 0, 0]

_outlet_area¶

outlet area

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_inlet_optimal_angle¶

optimal blade angle at inlet for the hub, mid and tip line.

Type:

3x1 array of floats, defaults to [0, 0, 0]

_parameter_angle¶

parameter used to define the blade shape using a cubic law. Must be between 0 and 1.

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_Ra¶

Surface roughness of the impeller and its blades

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_taperratio¶

taper ratio of the thickness for the blades.

Equals \(t_{\mathrm{hub}}/t_{\mathrm{tip}}\)

with \(t_{\mathrm{tip}}\) the thickness of the blade at the tip (_inlet_blade_thickness[-1] for instance)

and \(t_{\mathrm{hub}}\) the thickness of the blade at the hub (_inlet_blade_thickness[0] for instance)

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_tapertype¶

type of thickness evolution along the blade in the radial direction.

parabolic or linear.

When parabolic, the thickness \(t\) along the blade in the radial direction follows \(t(r) = 1 + \left(t_{\mathrm{tip}}/t_{\mathrm{hub}} - 1\right)r^2\)

When parabolic, the thickness \(t\) along the blade in the radial direction follows \(t(r) = 1 + \left(t_{\mathrm{tip}}/t_{\mathrm{hub}} - 1\right)r\)

Type:

float, defaults to 'parabolic'

_Xt¶

normalized radial distances in the radial/axial plane (meridional view) of the blade as an elliptic arc for different lines describing a blade. value is 0 for the hub and 1 for the tip of the blade.

1st result of a numpy.meshgrid with the number of lines to compute (along the radial direction of the blade) and the number of points in the axial direction. shape is (number of lines to computes, number of points on a line)

Type:

array of floats, defaults to None

_Theta¶

angles in radians to define the radial/axial plane (meridional view) of the blade as an elliptic arc for different lines describing a blade. value is 0 for the top of the impeller (inlet) and \(\pi/2\) for the outlet of the impeller.

2nd result of a numpy.meshgrid with the number of lines to compute (along the radial direction of the blade) and the number of points in the axial direction. shape is (number of lines to computes, number of points on a line)

Type:

array of floats, defaults to None

_r¶

radial coordinate in the meridional plane of the points to plot a blade from _Xt and _Theta

shape is (number of lines to computes, number of points on a line)

Type:

array of floats, defaults to None

_z¶

axial coordinate in the meridional plane of the points to plot a blade from _Xt and _Theta

shape is (number of lines to computes, number of points on a line)

Type:

array of floats, defaults to None

_mt¶

curvilinear distance along a blade using _r and _z

shape is (number of lines to computes, number of points on a line)

Type:

array of floats, defaults to None

_beta¶

blade angle in radians along the blade

shape is (number of lines to computes, number of points on a line)

Type:

array of floats, defaults to None

_phi¶

polar angle in radians of the blade for a 3D blade in cylindrical coordinates

shape is (number of lines to computes, number of points on a line)

Type:

array of floats, defaults to None

_mt_adim¶

normalized curvilinear distance along a blade, _mt/_mt[:, -1]

Type:

array of floats, defaults to None

_phi_allblades¶

polar angle in radians of the blades for 3D blades in cylindrical coordinates (see _phi)

shape is (_full_number_blade_w_splitters, number of lines to computes, number of points on a line)

Type:

array of floats, defaults to None

_inlet_diameters = [0, 0, 0]¶
_inlet_blade_thickness = [0, 0, 0]¶
_inlet_blade_angle = [0, 0, 0]¶
_outlet_diameter = 0¶
_outlet_blade_height = 0¶
_outlet_blade_thickness = 0¶
_outlet_average_blade_thickness = 0¶
_outlet_blade_angle = 0¶
_axial_extension = 0¶
_blade_running_clearance = 0¶
_number_blade_full = 0¶
_splitter_blade_length_fraction = 0¶
_blade_length = 0¶
_blade_length_meanline = 0¶
_effective_number_blade = 0¶
_full_number_blade_w_splitters = 0¶
_hydraulic_diameter = 0¶
_inlet_area = 0¶
_throat_pitch_blade = [0, 0, 0]¶
_throat_width = [0, 0, 0]¶
_throat_area = 0¶
_outlet_area = 0¶
_inlet_optimal_angle = [0, 0, 0]¶
_parameter_angle = 0¶
_Ra = 3.2¶
_taperratio = 1.5¶
_tapertype = 'parabolic'¶
_Xt = None¶
_Theta = None¶
_r = None¶
_z = None¶
_mt = None¶
_beta = None¶
_phi = None¶
_mt_adim = None¶
_phi_allblades = None¶
update_geometry(set_angle=False)¶

Computes impeller geometry data used for computation

  1. sets the thickness of the blades

  2. computes the mid line diameter

  3. computes the optimal inlet blade angles

  4. if set_angle is True, sets the inlet blade angles to optimal values

  5. computes the blade angle at the mean line (mid) of the inlet

  6. computes the blade length from :cite:t:`1970:Jansen`

  7. computes the effective number of blades and the full number of blades including splitters

  8. computes the hydraulic diameter from :cite:t:`1970:Jansen`

  9. computes the inlet flow area

  10. computes the throat flow area

  11. computes the outlet flow area

  12. computes the geometrical data to 3D plot the hub, mid and tip lines with 200 points along the blade in the axial direction

  13. computes the blade length at mean line (mid) from the 3D data

Parameters:

set_angle (bool, defaults to False) – define if inlet blade angles are modified to use the optimal angles or not

compute_mid_diameter()¶

Computes the mean (mid) line diameter and stores it it in the corresponding class attribute.

Updates _inlet_diameters[1] with \(D_{\mathrm{mid}} = \sqrt{\frac{D_{\mathrm{tip}}^2 + D_{\mathrm{hub}}^2}{2}}\)

compute_inlet_average_blade_angle()¶

Computes the average inlet blade angle and stores it in the corresponding class attribute.

Updates _inlet_blade_angle[1] with the interpolation of the inlet blade angle at the mean (mid) line diameter

compute_blade_length()¶

Computes blade length of an impeller and stores it in the corresponding class attribute _blade_length

Updates _blade_length \(L_{\mathrm{b}}\) with the blade length computed using :cite:t:`1970:Jansen`:

\(\mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_{\mathrm{average}}\right) = \frac{1}{2}\left(\mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_{1\ \mathrm{hub}}\right) + \mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_{1\ \mathrm{tip}}\right)\right)\) \(L_{\mathrm{b}} = \frac{\pi}{8} \left( D_2 - \frac{D_{\mathrm{tip}} + D_{\mathrm{hub}}}{2} - b_2 + 2 L_z \right) \frac{2}{\mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_{\mathrm{average}}\right) + \mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_2\right)}\)

compute_number_blade()¶

Computes the different number of blades and stores them in the corresponding class attribute.

Updates _full_number_blade_w_splitters \(N_{\mathrm{b}}\) as \(N_{\mathrm{b}} = 2N_{\mathrm{b\ full}}\) if _splitter_blade_length_fraction\(\in \left[10^{-5} ; 1\right[\) else \(N_{\mathrm{b}} = N_{\mathrm{b\ full}}\) where \(N_{\mathrm{b\ full}}\) is the number of full blades (ie. no splitter).

Updates _effective_number_blade \(N_{\mathrm{b\ effective}}\) as \(N_{\mathrm{b\ effective}} = N_{\mathrm{b\ full}}( 1 +\ \) _splitter_blade_length_fraction \()\) if _splitter_blade_length_fraction\(\in \left[10^{-5} ; 1\right[\) else \(N_{\mathrm{b\ effective}} = N_{\mathrm{b\ full}}\) where \(N_{\mathrm{b\ full}}\) is the number of full blades (ie. no splitter).

compute_hydraulic_diameter()¶

Computes the hydraulic diameter and stores it in the corresponding class attribute _hydraulic_diameter

Updates _hydraulic_diameter \(D_{\mathrm{hyd}}\) using :cite:t:`1970:Jansen`:

\(\mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_{\mathrm{average}}\right) = \frac{1}{2}\left(\mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_{1\ \mathrm{hub}}\right) + \mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_{1\ \mathrm{tip}}\right)\right)\)

\(\frac{D_{\mathrm{hyd}}}{D_2} = \frac{\mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_2\right)}{\frac{N_\mathrm{b\ effective}}{\pi} + D_2\frac{\mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_2\right)}{b_2}} + \frac{\frac{1}{2} \left(\frac{D_{1\ \mathrm{tip}}}{D_2} + \frac{D_{1\ \mathrm{hub}}}{D_2} \right) \mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_{\mathrm{average}} \right)}{\frac{N_{\mathrm{b\ effective}}}{\pi} + \frac{D_{1\ \mathrm{tip}} + D_{1\ \mathrm{hub}}}{D_{1\ \mathrm{tip}} - D_{1\ \mathrm{hub}}} \mathrm{cos}\left(\beta_{\mathrm{average}}\right)}\)

compute_inlet_area()¶

Computes the inlet area and stores it in the corresponding class attribute _inlet_area

Updates _inlet_area with \(\frac{\pi}{4} \left( D_{1\ \mathrm{tip}}^2 - D_{1\ \mathrm{hub}}^2 \right)\)

compute_pitch_blade(D, t)¶

Computes and returns the pitch of a blade at the inlet for a line along the blade situated at a diameter D and a thickness t

Computes and returns \(\pi D/N_{\mathrm{b\ full}} - t_1\) where \(D\) is the diameter where this is computed (hub, mid or tip) and \(t_1\) is the corresponding blade thickness.

Parameters:

  • D (float) – diameter of the line where the computation is done. hub, mid or tip typically.

  • t (float) – thickness of the blade at the diameter D

Returns:

s – max between 0 and the pitch of the blade at this position as \(\pi D/N_{\mathrm{b\ full}} - t_1\) where \(D\) is the diameter where this is computed (hub, mid or tip) and \(t_1\) is the corresponding blade thickness.

Return type:

float

Raises:

RuntimeError – When the pitch is negative or zero, the fluid can’t pass through

Note

The pitch of the blade is the distance between 2 blades at the diameter (ie how far are the 2 points defining the blade at the diameter of interest) and not the smallest distance between 2 blades which defines the throat.

compute_throat_area()¶

Computes the throat area for hub, mid and tip position and stores them in the corresponding class attribute.

  1. Updates _throat_pitch_blade using compute_pitch_blade()

  2. Updates _throat_width as \(o_i = s_i \mathrm{cos}\left( \beta_{1,\ i} \right)\) where \(o_i\) is the throat width of line \(i\) (hub, mid or tip), \(s_i\) is the blade pitch of line \(i\) from _throat_pitch_blade and \(\beta_{1,\ i}\) is the inlet blade angle for the line \(i\)

  3. Updates _throat_area using geometrical considerations and blockage due to diffusion according to :cite:t:`2000:Aungier`

    The geometrical passage area is given by \(\frac{N_{\mathrm{b\ full}}}{4} \left( o_{\mathrm{hub}}\left( D_{\mathrm{mid}} - D_{\mathrm{hub}} \right) + o_{\mathrm{mid}}\left( D_{\mathrm{tip}} - D_{\mathrm{hub}} \right) + o_{\mathrm{tip}}\left( D_{\mathrm{tip}} - D_{\mathrm{mid}} \right) \right)\)

    The reduction is given by \(AR = \frac{A_1 \mathrm{cos}\left( \beta_{1\ \mathrm{mid}} \right)}{A_{\mathrm{throat}}}\)

    If \(AR < 10^{-10}\) the throat area is not modified. Else, the throat area \(A_{\mathrm{throat}}\) is given by \(A_{\mathrm{throat}} = A_{\mathrm{throat}} \mathrm{min}\left( \sqrt{AR} \ ;\ 1 - (AR - 1)^2 \right)\)

compute_outlet_area()¶

Computes the outlet area and stores it in the corresponding class attribute _outlet_area.

Updates _outlet_area with \(\left( \pi D_2 - N_{\mathrm{b}} t_2 \right) b_2\)

compute_optimal_angle()¶

Computes the optimal inlet angles for hub, tip and mid and stores them in the corresponding class attribute _inlet_optimal_angle.

Updates _inlet_optimal_angle with \(\beta_{1\ \mathrm{opti}\ i} = \mathrm{arctan}\left( \frac{\pi D_{1\ i}}{\pi D_{1\ i} - N_{\mathrm{b\ full}} t_{1\ i}} \mathrm{tan}\left( \beta_{1\ i} \right)\right)\) with \(i\) standing for the line reference (hub, mid or tip)

Note

Verification TODO according to S. Parisi, p19 where \(\mathrm{tan}\left(\beta_{1\ \mathrm{opt}\ i}\right)/D_{1\ i} = (\omega/(2V_{1m})) = \mathrm{const.}\)

set_optimal_angle_overblade()¶

Sets _inlet_blade_angle using an optimal angle distribution derived from the rotation speed and meridional absolute velocity

Sets the different blades angles with \(\mathrm{tan}\left(\beta_{1\ \mathrm{opt}\ i}\right)/D_{1\ i} = (\omega/(2V_{1m})) = \mathrm{const.}\) where \(i\) stands for the line considered (hub, mid)

Note

Inlet tip blade angle _inlet_blade_angle[2] is set using value from _inlet_optimal_angle. The latter should be computed with compute_optimal_angle() by the user or another method before.

compute_fictitious_angle()¶

Computes and returns the fictitious angle used for the cubic law to generate the impeller geometry.

Compute and returns \(\beta_x = (1 - K)\left( \beta_{1\ \mathrm{hub}} + \beta_2 \right)/2\) used for the cubic law where \(K\) is a parameter of the model to adjust blade geometry stored in _parameter_angle From :cite:t:`2012:Parisi` equation 2.64.

Returns:

beta – Fictitious angle used in the cubic law \(\beta_x = (1 - K)\left( \beta_{1\ \mathrm{hub}} + \beta_2 \right)/2\) from :cite:t:`2012:Parisi` equation 2.64.

Return type:

float

compute_angle_parametersABC()¶

Computes and returns the polynomial parameters used for the cubic law to generate the impeller geometry.

The following equations are used, with \(\beta_x\) the fictitious angle given by compute_fictitious_angle():

\(A = -4 \beta_2 + 8 \beta_x - 4 \beta_{1\ \mathrm{hub}}\)

\(B = 11 \beta_2 - 16 \beta_x + 5 \beta_{1\ \mathrm{hub}}\)

\(C = -6 \beta_2 + 8 \beta_x - 2 \beta_{1\ \mathrm{hub}}\)

From :cite:t:`2012:Parisi` equation 2.63.

Returns:

A, B, C – polynomial parameters used in the cubic law

Return type:

tuple of floats

compute_tx(x)¶

Computes and returns the normalized blade thickness for a point of the blade at normalized radial distance x.

Depending on _tapertype returns:

\(t(x) = 1 + (t_{\mathrm{hub}}/t_{\mathrm{tip}} - 1 ) x^2\) if _tapertype is parabolic where \(t_{\mathrm{hub}}/t_{\mathrm{tip}}\) is stored in _taperratio

\(t(x) = 1 + (t_{\mathrm{hub}}/t_{\mathrm{tip}} - 1 ) x\) if _tapertype is linear where \(t_{\mathrm{hub}}/t_{\mathrm{tip}}\) is stored in _taperratio

raises a NotImplementedError else.

Parameters:

x (float) – Normalized radial distance between 0 (tip) and 1 (hub) where the normalized blade thickness is computed

Returns:

t(x) – Normalized blade thickness at point x depending on _tapertype value

Return type:

float

Raises:

NotImplementedError – If tapertype is not parabolic or linear.

Note

The x parameter goes from the tip (x = 0) to the hub (x = 1).

set_thicknesstaper()¶

Computes and stores the blade thicknesses in the corresponding class attributes

  1. Updates the hub blade thickness in _inlet_blade_thickness[0] using the tip blade thickness stored in _inlet_blade_thickness[2] and compute_tx().

  2. Updates the mid line (root mean square value) blade thickness _inlet_blade_thickness[1] using the tip blade thickness stored in _inlet_blade_thickness[2] and compute_tx().

  3. Updates the outlet average blade thickness _outlet_average_blade_thickness \(\left< t_2 \right>\) from the outlet tip blade thickness stored in _outlet_blade_thickness \(t_2\) and the _taperratio \(t_{\mathrm{hub}}/t_{\mathrm{tip}}\) with

    \(\left< t_2 \right> = \left( 1 + \frac{1}{2}\left( t_{\mathrm{hub}}/t_{\mathrm{tip}} - 1 \right) \right) t_2\) if _tapertype is parabolic

    \(\left< t_2 \right> = \left( 1 + \frac{1}{3}\left( t_{\mathrm{hub}}/t_{\mathrm{tip}} - 1 \right) \right) t_2\) if _tapertype is linear

    else raises NotImplementedError

Raises:

NotImplementedError – If tapertype is not parabolic or linear.

compute_radial_coordinate(xt, theta)¶

Computes and returns the radial coordinate in the meridional plane of the points to plot a blade from _Xt and _Theta

Radial coordinate is given by \(2r = D_2 - \left( D_2 - D_{1\ \mathrm{hub}} - x\left( D_{1\ \mathrm{tip}} - D_{1\ \mathrm{hub}} \right) \mathrm{cos} \left( \theta \right) \right)\) with \(x\) from argument xt the position along the blade from hub (0) to tip (1) and \(\theta\) from argument theta the angle description of the blade from inlet (0) to outlet (\(\pi/2\))

Parameters:

  • xt (numpy array of floats) – x position along the blade from hub (0) to tip (1)

  • theta (numpy array of floats) – angle description of the blade from inlet (0) to outlet (\(\pi/2\)) in radians

Returns:

r – radial coordinates of the points of the blade

Return type:

numpy array of floats

compute_axial_coordinate(xt, theta)¶

Computes and returns the axial coordinate of for an impeller using its position along the blade.

Axial coordinate is given by \(z = (-L_z + (x - 0.5)b_2)\mathrm{sin}\left(\theta\right)\) with \(L_z\) the axial extension of the blade stored in _axial_extension, \(x\) from argument xt the position along the blade from hub (0) to tip (1) and \(\theta\) from argument theta the angle description of the blade from inlet (0) to outlet (\(\pi/2\))

Parameters:

  • xt (numpy array of floats) – x position along the blade from hub (0) to tip (1)

  • theta (numpy array of floats) – angle description of the blade from inlet (0) to outlet (\(\pi/2\)) in radians

Returns:

z – axial coordinates of the points of the blade

Return type:

numpy array of floats

compute_curvilinear_abscissa(xt=None, theta=None, r=None, z=None)¶

Computes and returns the curvilinear abscissa along a blade similar to _mt but do not update it.

The curvilinear abscissa is given by \(m = \int \sqrt{\left( dr \right)^2 + \left( dz \right)^2}\) with \(dr\) an infinitesimal element of the radial coordinate and \(dz\) an infinitesimal element of the axial coordinate

Parameters:

  • xt (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – x position along the blade from hub (0) to tip (1)

  • theta (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – angle description of the blade from inlet (0) to outlet (\(\pi/2\)) in radians

  • r (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – radial coordinates of the points of the blade given by compute_radial_coordinate() if None, xt and theta are used to compute r

  • z (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – axial coordinates of the points of the blade given by compute_axial_coordinate() if None, xt and theta are used to compute z

Returns:

mt, z, r – arrays giving the curvilinear abscissa along a blade, axial and radial coordinates given by compute_radial_coordinate() and compute_axial_coordinate() respectively

Return type:

tuple of numpy arrays

compute_curvilinear_abscissa_adim(m)¶

Scales and returns the normalized curvilinear abscissa along a blade so that it’s between 0 and 1, similar to _mt_adim but do not update it.

The normalized curvilinear abscissa is given by \(\tilde{m} = m/m(\theta = \pi/2)\) for each line of the blade (x position).

Parameters:

m (numpy array of floats) – curvilinear abscissa along a blade given by the compute_curvilinear_abscissa()

Returns:

mt_adim – normalized curvilinear abscissa

Return type:

numpy array of floats

compute_angle_blade(xt=None, theta=None, r=None, z=None, mt=None)¶

Computes and returns the blade angles of the impeller blade, similar to _beta but do not update it

Using compute_angle_parametersABC() to get the A, B and C polynomial parameters, the blade angle are given by:

\(\beta_{\mathrm{hub}} = \beta_{1\ \mathrm{hub}} + A\tilde{m}(x = 0) + B\left(\tilde{m}(x = 0)\right)^2 + C\left(\tilde{m}(x = 0)\right)^3\)

\(\beta_{\mathrm{tip}} = \beta_{1\ \mathrm{tip}} + \left( \beta_2 - \beta_{1\ \mathrm{tip}} \right)\left( 3\left(\tilde{m}(x = 1)\right)^2 - 2\left(\tilde{m}(x = 1)\right)^3\right)\)

with 1 standing for inlet data, 2 standing for outlet data and \(\tilde{m}\) given by compute_curvilinear_abscissa_adim() or computed manually with compute_curvilinear_abscissa().

Parameters:

  • xt (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – x position along the blade from hub (0) to tip (1)

  • theta (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – angle description of the blade from inlet (0) to outlet (\(\pi/2\)) in radians

  • r (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – radial coordinates of the points of the blade given by compute_radial_coordinate() if None, xt and theta are used to compute r

  • z (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – axial coordinates of the points of the blade given by compute_axial_coordinate() if None, xt and theta are used to compute z

  • mt (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – curvilinear abscissa of the blades given by compute_curvilinear_abscissa() if None, will be computed using compute_curvilinear_abscissa()

Returns:

beta, mt, z, r – beta are the angles along the blade, the others are described in the Parameters section.

Return type:

tuple of numpy array of floats

interpolate_angle(angle, weight, eps=1e-12)¶

Computes and updates angle argument to interpolate between the two angles given by angle[:, 0] and angle[:, -1].

The interpolation of angles is given by: \(\alpha = \left( 2 \left( \alpha_{\mathrm{max}} - \alpha_{\mathrm{min}} \right) \% (2\pi) - \left( \alpha_{\mathrm{max}} - \alpha_{\mathrm{min}} \right) \right) x + \alpha_{\mathrm{min}}\)

with \(\alpha_{\mathrm{max}}\) given by angle[:, -1], \(\alpha_{\mathrm{min}}\) given by angle[:, 0] and \(x\) given by weight[:, i] for the point \(i\).

Parameters:

  • angle (array of floats of shape (n, m>2)) – angles in radians to interpolate. The columns (m) 0 and -1 are used as the two angles to interpolate from. Results are stored in columns 1:-1.

  • weight (array of floats of shape (n, m>2)) – should be the same shape as angle. Weight between 0 and 1 for the interpolation between angle[:, 0] (weight = 0) and angle[:, -1] (weight = 1).

  • eps (float, defaults to 1e-12) – precision to find zeros.

compute_polar_angle(xt=None, theta=None, r=None, z=None, mt=None, beta=None, adjustthickness=False)¶

Computes and returns the polar angle of an impeller blade, similar to _phi but do not update it

The polar angle is given by: \(\varphi(\tilde m) = \int \mathrm{tan}\left( \beta \right) \frac{dm}{r}\) with:

\(\tilde m\) the normalized curvilinear abscissa (see compute_curvilinear_abscissa_adim()),

\(m\) the curvilinear abscissa (see compute_curvilinear_abscissa()),

\(\beta\) the blade angle (see compute_angle_blade()) and

\(r\) the radial coordinate (see compute_radial_coordinate()).

The polar angle is computed for the hub and tip line then interpolated for each other xt positions between hub and tip with interpolate_angle().

When using the adjustthickness parameter, the thickness currently do not uses the thickness distribution profile given by _tapertype. For the inlet, the thickness is linearly interpolated using xt and _inlet_blade_thickness for hub and tip only. For the outlet, the thickness is taken constant and equals to _outlet_average_blade_thickness. Additionally, only one one value is modified for the inlet and for the outlet insofar as only the values for \(\theta = 0\) and \(\theta = \pi/2\) are modified leading to clunky contours when the descretization in theta is good for a smoot plot.

Parameters:

  • xt (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – x position along the blade from hub (0) to tip (1)

  • theta (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – angle description of the blade from inlet (0) to outlet (\(\pi/2\)) in radians

  • r (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – radial coordinates of the points of the blade given by compute_radial_coordinate() if None, xt and theta are used to compute r

  • z (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – axial coordinates of the points of the blade given by compute_axial_coordinate() if None, xt and theta are used to compute z

  • mt (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – curvilinear abscissa of the blades given by compute_curvilinear_abscissa() if None, will be computed using compute_curvilinear_abscissa()

  • beta (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – angles along the blade given by compute_angle_blade method() if None, will be computed using compute_angle_blade method()

  • adjustthickness (bool, defaults to False) – bool to adjust or not the angles on the pressure side (outlet) and suction side (inlet) with the thicknesses of the blade _outlet_average_blade_thickness and _inlet_blade_thickness respectively

Returns:

phi, beta, mt, z, r – phi stores the polar angles of the blades, the others are described in the Parameters section.

Return type:

tuple of numpy arrays of floats

Note

TODO Improve the adjustment of the angle with the thickness computation and thickness profile. See the corresponding paragraph in the detailed description of this function.

compute_polar_angle_repet(phi)¶

Computes and returns the polar angles of an impeller’s blade to plot all blades by doing a repetition of outputs from compute_polar_angle() using _full_number_blade_w_splitters.

Parameters:

phi (numpy array of floats) – polar angle of a blade given by compute_polar_angle()

Returns:

phi_allblades – array containing the polar angles for each blade

Return type:

numpy array of arrays of floats

cut_splitters(xt, mt, phi_allblades)¶

Compute and updates the polar angles of splitters to 0 when splitters are used and there shouldn’t be a value (no blade present due to the splitter’s length)

When splitters are not used (_splitter_blade_length_fraction >= 1 or self._splitter_blade_length_fraction <= 1e-5), does nothing.

Parameters:

  • xt (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – x position along the blade from hub (0) to tip (1)

  • mt (numpy array of floats, defaults to None) – curvilinear abscissa of the blades given by compute_curvilinear_abscissa() if None, will be computed using compute_curvilinear_abscissa()

  • phi_allblades (numpy array of floats) – array containing the polar angles for each blade given by compute_polar_angle_repet()

Note

TODO Improves the cutting process so that if only 2 lines are used (hub and tip), use self._blade_length to cut the blade

compute_blades(nb_additional_lines=0, nb_theta=200, adjustthickness=False)¶

Wrapper function to computes all the geometrical data to define the blades and stores them in the corresponding class attributes (_phi etc.).

Defines a numpy array holding each x position for (hub + tip + nb_additional_lines) lines and another numpy array for each \(\theta\) for each point where lines needs to be computed. These are used to define a numpy meshgrid.

Successively do: 1. Updates class attribute _r with compute_radial_coordinate(). 2. Updates class attribute _z with compute_axial_coordinate(). 3. Updates class attribute _mt with compute_curvilinear_abscissa(). 4. Updates class attribute _beta with compute_angle_blade(). 5. Updates class attribute _phi with compute_polar_angle(). 6. Updates class attribute _mt_adim with compute_curvilinear_abscissa_adim(). 8. Updates class attribute _phi_allblades with compute_curvilinear_abscissa(). 9. Updates class attribute _mt with compute_polar_angle_repet(). 10. Updates class atribute _phi_allblades with cut_splitters().

Parameters:

  • nb_additional_lines (int, defaults to 0) – Number of lines to plot in addition to the hub and tip lines. When equalts to 0, the mid line (corresponding to the root mean square value) is still computed.

  • nb_theta (int, defaults to 200) – Number points used to discretize a single line in terms of theta

  • adjustthickness (bool, defaults to False) – bool to adjust or not the angles on the pressure side (outlet) and suction side (inlet) with the thicknesses of the blade _outlet_average_blade_thickness and _inlet_blade_thickness respectively

Returns:

_phi_allblades, _mt_adim, _phi, _beta, _mt, _z, _r, _Xt, _Theta, theta, xt – Refers to class attributes documentation for the details.

Return type:

tuple of numpy array

compare_phi_find_param_angle(K)¶

Updates _parameter_angle with K[0] and calls compute_blades() to re-compute the blade geometry

This function is usually used to define a _parameter_angle so that the blade at the outlet is perfectly vertical using an optimization function such as scipy.optimize.minimize.

Parameters:

K (array of float of size 1) – array containing the new value of _parameter_angle in K[0]. Should be between 0 and 1.

Returns:

delta – absolute value of the difference of polar angles at the outlet for tip and hub lines: \(\left| \varphi_{2\ \mathrm{tip}} - \varphi_{2\ \mathrm{hub}} \right|\)

Return type:

float

class geometry.VanelessDiffuser¶

Class defining and holding all geometrical data for the vaneless diffuser of a centrifugal machine

_outlet_diameter¶

Outlet diameter of the vaneless diffuser

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_outlet_height¶

Outlet height of the vaneless diffuser

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_outlet_area¶

Outlet area of the vaneless diffuser

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_outlet_diameter_old¶

Previous outlet diameter of the vaneless diffuser when updated with update_outlet_diameter()

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_outlet_diameter = 0¶
_outlet_height = 0¶
_outlet_area = 0¶
_outlet_diameter_old = 0¶
compute_area()¶

Computes and updates the outlet area of the vaneless diffuser, stores it in _outlet_area

update_outlet_diameter(delta)¶

Computes and updates the outlet diameter of the vaneless diffuser, stores it in _outlet_diameter

The current value of _outlet_diameter is stored in _outlet_diameter_old.

The new value of _outlet_diameter is _outlet_diameter + delta.

Parameters:

delta (float) – increase in outlet diameter _outlet_diameter to add.

class geometry.Volute¶

Class defining and holding all geometrical data for the volute of a centrifugal machine

The volute is supposed axi-symmetric with a flat bottom for half of the circle diameter

_D¶

diameter of the circle defining the volute area

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_area¶

area of a cross-section of the volute

Type:

float, defaults to 0

_D = 0¶
_area = 0¶
compute_area_circularsegment(h)¶

Computes and returns the area of a circular segment (in the circle) for a line intersecting a circle at a height of h from the bottom of the circle.

Maths explained in Mathworld

Parameters:

h (float) – height of the line intersecting the circle

Returns:

A – area of the circle between the circular segment and the line at height h.

Return type:

float

compute_outlet_area(diffuser_outlet_height)¶

Computes, updates and returns the area of the volute _area including the small part that comes from the diffuser intersecting the circle

Parameters:

diffuser_outlet_height (float) – diffuser’s outlet height ie. height of the line intersecting the circle defining the volute.

solve_diameter(diffuser_area, diffuser_outlet_height)¶

Computes and updates the volute diameter _D and area _area.

Using scipy.optimize.brentq on function_to_optimize(), the diameter _D is set. The area _area is then updated with the new diameter _D found.

Parameters:

  • diffuser_area (float) – area of the diffuser studied. Usually _area but the function could be called with another one because the functions do not specifically depend on this instance.

  • diffuser_outlet_height (float) – height of the diffuser studied. Used as the lower bound for the brentq function. 1000 diffuser_outlet_height used as the higher bound of the brentq function.

function_to_optimize(x, diffuser_outlet_height, obj)¶

Sets the volute diameter _D with input, updates the area _area and returns the difference of the new area with input obj

Parameters:

  • x (float) – new value of volute diameter _D.

  • diffuser_outlet_height (float) – height of the diffuser studied.

  • obj (float) – Usually the previous volute area value.

Returns:

diff – arithmetic difference of the new value of the area _area with the old value given as a parameter by obj.

Return type:

float

find_offset_diffuser(h)¶

Computes and returns the radial position of the intersection of the diffuser with the volute where the diffuser is of height h given as the parameter.

The intersection of the diffuser with the volute is defined as a height. Therefore, when doing the intersection with a circle, the radial position of such intersection may be different than initially used in the code. This function computes the radial position of such intersection to update it in the code according to the geometric definition of the volute. This is then in turns used in update_outlet_diameter().

Parameters:

h (float) – Height of the diffuser when it meets the volute

Returns:

delta – returns the difference of the radial position of the point where the diffuser intersects the volute to be used in update_outlet_diameter()

Return type:

float
